_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Clay Center Terminal & Storage
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

At the Enterprise Clay Center Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Clay Center Terminal and Storage is owned by Enterprise Terminals & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and is operated by Enterprise Products Operating, LLC..  

We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Clay Center Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Clay Center facility is a pipeline, storage and transport truck loading facility.  The pipeline system is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pipeline system which is regulated by the Department of Transportation.  The propane storage and loading facilities are regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The Cla

y Center Terminal has two pipelines that are routed through the facility and are regulated by the Department of Transportation.  These two pipelines are a multiple product line (natural gasoline, naphtha, normal butane, iso-butane and propane) and a dedicated propane line both owned by Mid-America Pipeline Company, LLC.  Both pipelines are operated by Enterprise Products Operating LLC.  In addition, the facility receives propane from the dedicated propane pipeline into two propane storage tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks which also has capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies.  Both of the propane storage tanks  are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed a maximum capacity of 80% full.  If necessary, the facility can also receive and store propane taken from the mixed product pipeline.

In our facility we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

There are no toxic chemicals handled by the Enterprise operations at the Clay Center Terminal.

Flammables

Propane is a finished product which can be delivered into the two storage tanks via the dedicated propane pipeline, or the mixed product pipeline.  This material is routed from these tanks to the truck transport loading docks for wholesale delivery to propane retailers.  Flammable  Ethyl Mercaptan is also present at the terminal for use as a propane odorant, but the amount of Ethyl Mercaptan on site is less than the threshold quantity specified in the RMP regulation.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenario and alternative release scenariofor our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposur

e distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no toxic chemicals handled by the Enterprise Clay Center propane terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no toxic chemicals handled by the Enterprise Clay Center propane terminal.

Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of one of the two identical propane storage tanks resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario would not be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting section of the Risk Management Plan

Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 500 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 21,151 pounds of material would be released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  This consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  This scenario would be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is c

ontained in the alternate release scenario section of the RMP registration.  

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an Integrated Contingency Plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Clay County LEPC, which includes the local Police department, Sheriff?s Department, Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, the local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the emergency notification alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Clay County Sheriff?s Department and local Fire Departments.  Remote activation can also be accomplished from the system?s control center which is based in Houston, Texas.  The Enterprise Houston Control Center has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shutdown remotely from Houston Control or locally by Operations.  A third party contractor, 3E is under contract to effectively contact the necessary agencies if required.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise Products takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety i

nformation
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of the prevention efforts, there are a multitude of programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which the Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.

The Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazardous materials.  Enterprise Products Operating LLC is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Facility safety is a primary goal at Enterpirse.  The Clay Center Terminal promptly addesses safety recommendations from process hazard analyses conducted at the facility.  Safety management program improvements recommended as a result of internal facility program audits are

also acted upon to insure prompt correction.  Safety recommendations made by location employees are considered and implemented if the proposal can be shown to improve facility safety.  The facility safety management (PSM) system is reviewed on a continuing basis with the goal of an improved safety program and a safe facility as a result.

The following is a list of reviews and/or improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The terminal has proposed a budget item to install a new motor control center inside a building to replace the current outdoor control center.  This project, upon approval, would reduce the chances of the control center serving as an ignition source for any flammable vapors that might be released into the terminal area..
